description: Dive into "Stuttgart Snapshots: Capturing the City‚Äôs Essence" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Stuttgart Snapshots: Capturing the City‚Äôs Essence

places.generalDescription: A

sources.snippet: At Zuffenhausen, a little way up the road from Stuttgart, are the headquarters of another automobile brand of international fame. The Porsche Museum has been around since the 70s but got a stylish redesign ten years ago and reopened in 2009. The museum uncovers the early days of the brand, and recounts the many innovations of engineer and founder, Professor Ferdinand Porsche, the man who invented the VW Beetle and the first gasoline-electric hybrid.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Stuttgart (Germany)

sources.snippet: Porsche's vehicles, with their sexy lines and powerful engines, have been aspirational cars for generations. If you want your own dose of inspiration, head to the Porsche Museum where the company's history and cars are on display at this world-class museum. Take the long elevator ride up to the museum floor and be prepared to be awed.
sources.shortName: Attractions & Things to Do in Stuttgart

sources.snippet: If you are a fan of fast cars, then the Porsche-Museum is a must-see. The building is quite spectacular as well, so if you are an avid photographer, then there are actually two reasons to visit!. The museum is a bit smaller than the Mercedes-Benz museum and there are only a bit less than 100 vehicles on display.
sources.shortName: The top 15 things to do in Stuttgart, Germany [A local's guide]

sources.snippet: After Mercedes one, we are heading to another car museum that should not be missed during your time in Stuttgart. Ferdinand Porsche was born in this building in Liberec in 1875. Ferdinand Porsche's engineering spirit is at the heart of the exhibition.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Stuttgart

sources.snippet: As Stuttgart is a city of cars, there‚Äôs another car museum worth visiting ‚Äì the Porsche Museum. The museum is located in Zuffenhausen, Northwest of Stuttgart and further than the Mercedes Museum.
sources.shortName: 28 Unique Things To Do in Stuttgart, Germany [2025] -

places.name: Porsche Museum

reviews.text:
Amazing place for petrol heads. Come early to get a good parking spot. Love that kids have a reduced ticket.
All the cars displayed are beautiful and showcase how time has affected change in the newer builds. The whole museum can be covered in 2-4 hours. Depending on the level of time you have at hand.
The interactive race was what my son enjoyed the most. But a pic with Sally is a must. I should warn you, the gift shop is where you will spend a lot of money. There is a lot that you will like there so better come prepared.

The museum is well curated. A must for a Porsche fan or a good place to see nice cars for any car enthusiasts. You'll probably spend an hour to finish the whole thing or could go up to 3 hours if you want to go into details of each car and its story.

Open on Sunday with a cafe and two restaurants inside. The cafe is average, all good design but not as good coffee. The restaurant serve nice food with reasonable price.

The weather was perfect on the day of our Porsche Museum visit, which made the whole experience even more enjoyable. The sleek, modern architecture of the building stood out beautifully under the clear skies. Inside, the collection was absolutely stunning ‚Äì from vintage classics to futuristic prototypes. Each exhibit was thoughtfully displayed, with great attention to detail and interactive elements. The atmosphere was relaxed yet inspiring. Friendly staff and well-organized layouts made it easy to explore.

places.generalDescription: The Mercedes-Benz Museum in Stuttgart offers a captivating journey through 125 years of automotive history, showcasing vintage and modern vehicles that have shaped the car industry. The museum's sleek architecture mirrors the curves of high-speed race cars, setting the stage for an impressive collection that appeals to both avid car enthusiasts and those with a passing interest in automotive engineering. Visitors can explore key historical events intertwined with the evolution of automobiles, including poignant memories captured in photographs.

sources.snippet: This museum is somewhat of a pilgrimage site for car enthusiasts ‚Äì and it‚Äôs no wonder. Every floor of the building, which in itself is a remarkable feat of engineering, pays homage to one of the most beautiful and influential cars ever built. The museum sheds light not only on the evolution and mechanics of the models but also how this brand and its founder, Mercedes-Daimler-Benz, have played an instrumental role in the shaping of modern German history.
sources.shortName: Top Things To Do And See In Stuttgart, Germany

sources.snippet: The Mercedes Benz Museum is more than a museum dedicated to vehicles, this huge museum (over 180,000 square feet) covers 130 years of automobile history and changes in society and world events, including both world wars. Cars, buses, and even the Popemobile and the SUV used in the movie Jurassic Park are on display, along with race cars and airplane engines. The building itself is an attraction, an architectural marvel in the form of a double helix.
sources.shortName: Attractions & Things to Do in Stuttgart

sources.snippet: We will not be making any mistakes if we say that this museum is one of the best places to visit in Stuttgart. The car invented by Carl Benz in 1886 is honoured by the Mercedes-Benz Museum in Stuttgart: it relates its history and shares its tales, keeping both alive by setting them in the context of information systems, day-to-day life, social history and popular culture. The main characters involve more than 160 cars of all sizes.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Stuttgart

sources.snippet: The modern automobile was invented by Karl Benz, with his patent of the ‚ÄúMotorwagen‚Äù in 1886 and the ‚ÄúMercedes‚Äù part of the name comes from an associate, Emil Jellinek‚Äôs daughter‚Äôs name ‚ÄúMercedes‚Äù. One of the most famous places to visit in Germany is the Mercedes-Benz Museum. An impressive structure that dominates the skyline with its double helix interior designed to maximize space and proudly displays 160 vehicles!
sources.shortName: 17 UNIQUE Things to Do in Stuttgart [in 2024]

sources.snippet: Visiting the Mercedes-Benz Museum, in a curved metallic building with a double helix, is partly a journey back to the birth of the automobile. Karl Benz invented what is considered the first true car in 1886. The double helix design allows for two parallel audio-guided tours; one dipping into the distinguished history of the brand, and the other showing the great diversity of vehicles manufactured by Mercedes-Benz.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Stuttgart (Germany)

sources.snippet: Denn hier wurde vor 135 Jahren nahezu zeitgleich von Carl Benz und Gottlieb Daimler das Automobil erfunden. Im Jahr 1886 meldete Carl Benz in Mannheim das Patent f√ºr seinen dreir√§drigen Motorwagen an. Zur gleichen Zeit entwickelten in einer kleinen Stuttgarter Werkstatt Gottlieb Daimler und Wilhelm Maybach den ersten vierr√§drigen Kraftwagen der Welt.
sources.shortName: 15 Sehensw√ºrdigkeiten, Fotospots & Aktivit√§ten

sources.snippet: I‚Äôm not sure Stuttgart would be the same city it is today, without the invention of the first gasoline-powered car in 1886. Daimler, Mercedes, Maybach ‚Äì some of the most important household names in the whole car industry converge in Stuttgart. Even 140 years later, the car industry still dominates Stuttgart.
sources.shortName: The top 15 things to do in Stuttgart, Germany [A local's guide]

sources.snippet: Das Museum befindet sich in Bad Cannstatt und ist ein weiterer Hingucker, wenn es um moderne Architektur geht. Um den Innenkern des Geb√§udes winden sich Ebenen, die an eine Doppelhelix der DNA erinnern sollen. Eine Glasfassade ziert die W√§nde au√üen.
sources.siteName: Vereinigung Stuttgarter Studentenwohnheime e.V. | Studentenwohnheime in Stuttgart
sources.shortName: 5 Instagram worthy spots in Stuttgart

sources.snippet: Das Mercedes-Benz-Museum wurde 2006 in der Mercedes-Benz-Welt in Stuttgart Bad Cannstadt wiederer√∂ffnet. Auf 3.500 m¬≤ Grundfl√§che √ºber neun Geschosse verteilt finden sich viele Exponate der Automobilgeschichte.
sources.shortName: Fotospots und Ausflugsziele in der Umgebung

sources.snippet: The city is home to many automakers including Mercedes (Daimler) and Porsche. The Mercedes Museum is a multi-story complex that winds it‚Äôs way up, taking you through over 125 years of car history.
sources.shortName: 28 Unique Things To Do in Stuttgart, Germany [2025] -
Dein Street Photography Guide f√ºr Stuttgart (2024)
Local Photographers Choose :The Best Spots For Photography In Stuttgart

places.name: Mercedes-Benz Museum

reviews.text:
I really enjoyed my visit to the Mercedes-Benz Museum in Stuttgart. The building is spectacular, and the way the exhibitions are laid out makes it easy to follow the history of the automobile from the very beginning up to modern times. The variety of vehicles on display is impressive, from the earliest cars to racing legends and special one-offs. It's a place where you could easily spend hours without noticing the time pass.

Most of the staff were exactly what you would expect in a museum of this caliber: welcoming, polite, and professional. But unfortunately, one staff member (see photo) stood out in the worst possible way. She was stationed at the entrance to remind people about the rules regarding bags and drinks, which is of course a necessary task. However, instead of doing it in a respectful or friendly manner, she came across as outright rude. It wasn't just with us-she seemed to treat every visitor in the same abrupt and dismissive way.

There are countless ways to enforce rules while still showing basic respect, but she chose the opposite approach. Zero sense of social competence, and frankly the wrong person for that job. It left a very sour taste and is something the management should take seriously. One unfriendly encounter can damage the atmosphere that the rest of the staff work so hard to create.

That said, the museum itself is absolutely worth visiting. The cars, the architecture, and the storytelling are world-class. But I sincerely hope the management reconsiders who they put in front of guests, because one person's behavior should not be allowed to drag down an otherwise fantastic experience.

Highly recommend, amazing car with professionally designed museum layout. A lift will take you to the top floor and you will walk down to the first floor. I the halls connecting the floors there are historical pictures so you can easily correlate the cars to the history like Kennedy presidency or man on the moon. This makes it absolutely easy to understand when that car were rushing through streets!

I was very pleased with my visit to the Mercedes-Benz Museum. It's an excellent combination of showcasing the evolution of Mercedes and the broader progress of German industry and society throughout history. The exhibitions are modern, rich in content, and interesting for both adults and children. The entire space is clean, spacious, and very well organized. I recommend buying tickets online ‚Äì it's easy and helps avoid waiting. There's also a large, convenient parking area. This museum is a must-see for anyone visiting Stuttgart!

places.generalDescription: Wilhelma Zoological and Botanic Garden is a vast zoo and botanical garden located in a former royal park dating back to the 19th century. Originally created as a private retreat for Swabian King Wilhelm, it has now become one of Germany's largest zoos, attracting over two million visitors annually. The site features Neo-Moorish style buildings set amidst lush gardens, offering a unique setting for its diverse collection of animals and plants.

sources.snippet: In Wilhelma Zoo and Botanical Gardens you can achieve a feeling of complete relaxation, while also being thoroughly entertained. There is an expanse of stunning gardens and intricate greenhouses, and the striking 19th century-style architecture to explore and enjoy before visiting the many members of the animal kingdom who call this zoo home. All animals here are completely content and their antics from within their safe settings will amaze and greatly amuse you.
sources.shortName: Top Things To Do And See In Stuttgart, Germany

sources.snippet: This much-loved zoo and botanical garden is in the north of Stuttgart on the grounds of a royal palace. The Wilhelma was first landscaped as a pleasure park during the reign of William I, and he picked a Moorish Revival theme for the royal bathhouse, which is a miniature version of the Alhambra in Granada. The park opened to the public in 1880 and was rebuilt as a zoo following damage in the war.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Stuttgart (Germany)

sources.snippet: Although this is one of Europe's largest zoological parks, visitors from North America could be forgiven for thinking that it feels small, and compared to what you find in San Diego or other major centers, it is. What is most impressive is the Neo-Moorish architecture, a good selection of unique animals, and stunning botanical gardens. The zoological park is a fantastic family outing.
sources.shortName: Attractions & Things to Do in Stuttgart

sources.snippet: It‚Äôs a huge zoo and botanical garden built in a historical park. It‚Äôs both among the most visited and most popular zoos in Germany and their great-ape projects have been setting new standards for the breeding of these endangered species since 1972. It‚Äôs one of the best things to do in Stuttgart with kids and quite an enjoyable place to go for a walk.
sources.shortName: The top 15 things to do in Stuttgart, Germany [A local's guide]

sources.snippet: Wilhelma in Stuttgart is a real highlight for anyone who loves nature and architecture. Stroll through the impressive greenhouses, admire exotic plants and discover the beautiful zoo. The green oases and lush gardens are perfect for switching off and enjoying the diversity of nature in the middle of the city.
sources.shortName: Discover Stuttgart's green side: Top places and parks to relax

sources.snippet: Right in the heart of the city, Wilhelma Zoo is a beautiful zoo with a large variety of animal species. It is also home to the only zoological-botanical gardens in Germany with over 7,000 species of plants. In the summer the zoo is a magnificent display of color and greenery.
sources.shortName: 28 Unique Things To Do in Stuttgart, Germany [2025] -

sources.snippet: Manche m√∂gen Orte mit wilderer Natur bevorzugen, aber abwechslungsreicher und exotischer als hier findet Ihr nichts: mehr als 8000 Pflanzenarten, Tiere aus aller Welt, der einfach umwerfende Seerosenteich und nat√ºrlich die Geb√§ude im maurischen Stil.
sources.shortName: Die 7 besten Fotospots in Stuttgart

sources.snippet: Die Wilhelma in Stuttgart ist eine historische Schlossanlage und gleichzeitig ein gro√üer Zoo und botanischer Garten. Das Gel√§nde ist sehr fotografenfreundlich und deshalb ein hervorragender Platz f√ºr Tier- und Pflanzenfotografie.
sources.shortName: Fotospots und Ausflugsziele in der Umgebung

sources.snippet: Maurische Bauwerke, seltene exotische Pflanzen (√ºber 8000 Pflanzenarten!), der wundersch√∂ne Seerosenteich ‚Äì und nat√ºrlich jede Menge Tiere!. Im zoologisch-botanischen Garten Wilhelma warten unz√§hlige Motive auf Entdeckung.
sources.shortName: Top 10: Foto Spots

sources.snippet: Der Stuttgarter Zoo, die Wilhelma eignet sich f√ºr Tier und Pflanzenaufnahmen. Die Gew√§chsh√§user bieten die M√∂glichkeit zur Fotografie von tropischen Pflanzen. Exotische Tiere lassen sich aus sicherer Entfernung ablichten.
sources.shortName: Die 33 besten Fotospots + Tipps zum Fotografieren in Stuttgart
Local Photographers Choose :The Best Spots For Photography In Stuttgart

places.name: Wilhelma - Zoological-botanical garden

reviews.text:
The Wilhelma Zoo and Botanical Garden in Stuttgart is truly an incredible place! I honestly didn't expect it to be so impressive. The grounds are spacious, green, and absolutely beautiful - full of flowers, trees, and charming historic buildings. Walking through it feels like strolling through a fairytale park.

There's a huge variety of animals - from elephants and giraffes to the cutest koalas and vibrant tropical birds. The butterfly house was especially unforgettable - it's pure magic watching butterflies fly right past you. And the monkeys and penguins? Totally captivating!

The whole area is so cozy and thoughtfully designed, with plenty of benches, caf√©s, and quiet places to relax. You can tell the animals are well cared for, and everything is done with love. It's definitely one of the most wonderful places I've ever visited. If you're ever in Stuttgart - don't miss it!And if it were possible I would give it 10 stars, I'm delighted!üòçüòç

The best zoo in the world. I've been to all the London zoos and lots more throughout the UK and internationally - this must be the best zoo ever!
It's spacious, beautiful, clean. It wasn't busy or crowded at all, even on a Sunday.
Also it's huge with so many animals! Which on the whole seem happy and looked after. And the gardens and greenhouses are stunning.
Even the food and canteens/restaurants are lovely.
We had the best day ever. And there's so many play areas for kids as well. 10/10 you have to come if you're in the area. You won't regret it.

Beautiful garden + zoo which is so nicely maintained. The garden is spectacular. There is the cactus area which would mesmerize all garden lovers. The surroundings are well kept. The Amazon experience is amazing. The animals can be viewed closely, that's how the landscaping is done for their enclosures. Multiple restaurants are within the Wilhelma zoo.
Not to forget some lucky ones even got peacock feathers. We visited on a Saturday with kids and it was a day well spent.

places.generalDescription: H√∂henpark Killesberg is a 50-hectare green oasis in the heart of Stuttgart, originally designed for the Reichsgartenschau in 1939. The park boasts beautiful flowers, cacti, and plants, as well as a park train, a summer fairground, an animal enclosure, and an annual Dahlia show. Visitors can enjoy stunning views from the 40-meter-high tower and explore various sculptures and fountains throughout the park.

sources.snippet: Der 50 Hektar gro√üe H√∂henpark Killesberg ist eine richtig gr√ºne Oase mitten in der Stadt und eines der beliebtesten Naherholungsgebiete der Stuttgarter. Die Entstehung des Parks geht auf das Jahr 1939 zur√ºck, als St√§dteplaner den Park anl√§sslich der Reichsgartenschau anlegen lie√üen. Der Park hat f√ºr Klein und Gro√ü jede Menge zu bieten: wundersch√∂n bl√ºhende Blumen, Kakteen und Pflanzen, eine Parkbahn, einen Jahrmarkt in den Sommermonaten, ein Tiergehege, eine j√§hrlich stattfindende Dahlienshow und vieles mehr.
sources.shortName: 15 Sehensw√ºrdigkeiten, Fotospots & Aktivit√§ten

sources.snippet: Ein schwindelerregender Aussichtsturm, ein historischer Jahrmarkt, schier endlose Blumenfelder (mit saisonalen Highlights!), die fotogene Skulptur ‚ÄûStangenwald‚Äú: Im H√∂henpark Killesberg wimmelt es geradezu von lohnenswerten Motiven f√ºr einen fotografischen Spaziergang. Und die faszinierende Weissenhofsiedlung ist auch gleich um die Ecke ‚Äì ein architektonisches Highlight mit dem UNESCO-Weltkulturerbe Le Corbusier.
sources.shortName: Top 10: Foto Spots

sources.snippet: Killesberg hat einfach alles: einen historischen Jahrmarkt, unendliche Blumenfelder, die mittlerweile mythischen Parkeisenbahn und den Aussichtsturm √ºber allem. Selbst ein Einarmiger mit einem Nokia 3310 k√∂nnte hier gute Bilder machen. A post shared by Martin H√∂rnicke (@hoernchen.entdeckt.die.welt)
sources.shortName: Die 7 besten Fotospots in Stuttgart
Local Photographers Choose :The Best Spots For Photography In Stuttgart

places.name: H√∂henpark Killesberg

reviews.text: I love this park. It is so beautiful and peaceful. Def a must visit several times a year as the landscape is constantly changing and more beautiful then the last time you saw it. The turm, the train, the water features and all the animals are wonderful additions to an outing here.

Excellent park! It just goes on and on with more things to discover. We especially enjoyed the ease to reach it from the city, the tower and the views it offered, the little carnival area, the rose gardens, and the children's theatre. Will definitely come here again.

A nice and calm spot. Would recommend going on a sunny day for an ideal experience.
On a side note, they got the cutest geese/ducks I've ever seen!

places.generalDescription: Schloss Solitude, a stunning rococo palace built between 1764 and 1769 for Duke Carl Eugen, is a must-visit gem located just outside Stuttgart. This magnificent structure not only boasts breathtaking views but also features delightful hiking trails that invite exploration of the surrounding lush forests. As you wander through its opulent halls, you'll discover fascinating artifacts from its history as a private hunting lodge. The serene gardens offer a perfect backdrop for memorable moments with friends or family.

sources.snippet: Stuttgart Palace, also known as The Schloss of Solitude, is a glorious place to visit on the outskirts of Stuttgart and fascinating in-depth tours inside the building are available regularly. Originally built by a former duke of W√ºrttemberg as a private hunting lodge, there are all kinds of prizes and paraphernalia to behold once you get inside. The surrounding gardens and woods are also a real treat to explore, especially with loved ones.
sources.shortName: Top Things To Do And See In Stuttgart, Germany

sources.snippet: Located on a scenic vantage point a few miles outside of Stuttgart's city center, Schloss Solitude (Solitude Palace) was built for Duke Karl Eugen in 1763 as a hunting lodge and summer residence. Designed in the late Rococo and early Neoclassical styles, the most sumptuously decorated rooms are in the central pavilion. Its highlight is the radiant Weisse Saal (White Hall) with its lovely domed roof, intricate decorative goldwork, and frescoed ceiling.
sources.shortName: Attractions & Things to Do in Stuttgart

sources.snippet: Das wundersch√∂ne Schloss, welches 1763 von Herzog Carl Eugen von W√ºrttemberg als Jagdschloss errichtet wurde, liegt direkt in Stuttgart-West. Es ist nicht nur eine tolle Eventlocation, sondern ist auch eine der sch√∂nsten Fotolocations in Stuttgart und Umgebung. Hier werden regelm√§√üig Hochzeits-Shootings veranstaltet und bei einem Besuch kannst du zugleich den tollen Weitblick bis fast nach Ludwigsburg begutachten.
sources.shortName: Die sch√∂nsten Foto Locations, Instagram-Spots, Tipps und Sehensw√ºrdigkeiten in Stuttgart - inspirationdelavie

sources.snippet: Etwa 10 km von der Stuttgarter Innenstadt entfernt, liegt auf einer Anh√∂he im Westen der Stadt das zwischen 1763 und 1769 f√ºr Herzog Carl Eugen von W√ºrttemberg erbaute Schloss Solitude. Das Jagd- und Repr√§sentationsschloss ist w√§hrend seiner Geschichte von nachfolgenden Generationen nie umgestaltet und auch nicht im Zweiten Weltkrieg zerst√∂rt worden. Seit der zweiten H√§lfte des 20.
sources.shortName: 15 Sehensw√ºrdigkeiten, Fotospots & Aktivit√§ten

sources.snippet: This magnificent palace already appeared in the list of gorgeous castles to get married in Germany, and it is definitely worth of being listed again. The Schloss Solitude is a wonderful venue for medium or large weddings. Its rooms are among the most beautiful places created in the Duchy of W√ºrttemberg in the 18th century.
sources.shortName: 8 of the best wedding venues in Stuttgart and around

sources.snippet: Diesem barocken architektonischen Juwel haben wir bereits einen ausf√ºhrlichen Artikel gewidmet. Denn Herzog Carl Eugens Sommerresidenz bietet zu jeder Jahreszeit ‚Äì besonders im Winterschnee ‚Äì wundersch√∂ne Aussichten und einen 13 km langen Weg durch seine Parkanlagen bis nach Ludwigsburg, der absolut wanderw√ºrdig ist.
sources.shortName: Die 7 besten Fotospots in Stuttgart

sources.snippet: Located west of Stuttgart just outside of the city, Schloss Solitude is a large palace built high on a hilltop. The views are great and the grounds are large with many trails and a large lawn area out front. Duke Carl Eugen von W√ºrttemberg built the palace in 1763 to be a lodge and hunting grounds.
sources.shortName: 28 Unique Things To Do in Stuttgart, Germany [2025] -

sources.snippet: Another one of the top places to visit in Stuttgart is this castle. The Isolation Palace is a Rococo chateau and hunting resort commissioned by the Duke of Wurttemberg, Charles Eugene. The east wing is made up of guest lounges, including two halls and four cabinets.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Stuttgart

sources.snippet: The castle impresses with its magnificent architecture and breathtaking views. Stroll through the extensive gardens and let yourself be carried away by the relaxed atmosphere of this historic place. Ideal for a chilled-out day and a break from everyday life.
sources.shortName: Discover Stuttgart's green side: Top places and parks to relax
Local Photographers Choose :The Best Spots For Photography In Stuttgart

places.name: Schloss Solitude

reviews.text: Very nice place to walk by, have a picnic or just chill in the sun. It is free to go around and there is a cafe nearby. At the forest, there is some barbecue area. Although, there is no stairs to walk around the castle, the pathway is a little tricky for wheelchairs users.

Schloss Solitude is a stunning Rococo palace with breathtaking views over Stuttgart. The architecture is elegant, and the surrounding nature makes it a perfect escape from the city's hustle and bustle. Whether you're here for a picnic, a walk through the forest, or simply to admire the sunset, the atmosphere is always serene.

The viewing platform offers fantastic panoramic views, and the walking trails around the palace make it a great spot for leisure activities. While the palace interior is only accessible via guided tours, the exterior alone is worth the visit. Highly recommended for anyone looking for a peaceful retreat with historical charm.

There is a sign "No cars allowed" at the entrance of the alley, leading to the castle - 400m. One with disabilities would have difficulties. Please note that at the end there are 2 parking places and a charger for e-vehicles.

places.generalDescription: Schlossplatz is a central square in Stuttgart, known for its gardens and the 1841 Jubilee Column. It's a hub of cultural activity with open-air concerts and summer festivals. The area also showcases modern sculptures by renowned artists like Alexander Calder, Alfred Hrdlicka, and Otto Hajek. Street art enthusiasts will appreciate the city's creative scene, including a popular tourist attraction called the Hall of Fame in Bad Cannstatt.

sources.snippet: Kaum jemand wei√ü, wie viele interessante Locations f√ºr Stra√üenfotografen in Stuttgart zu finden sind. Ob in West-Stuttgart, am Bahnhofsturm oder im SI-Centrum: die Stadt bietet eine riesige Auswahl an Pl√§tzen, die optimal f√ºr Street Fotografie geeignet sind. Der Stuttgarter Fotograf Sven Scholz, der auch leidenschaftlicher Street Photographer ist, beweist das eindrucksvoll auf seiner Website.
sources.shortName: Dein Street Photography Guide f√ºr Stuttgart (2024)
Local Photographers Choose :The Best Spots For Photography In Stuttgart

places.name: Schlossplatz

reviews.text: Some places aren't just beautiful - they speak to something inside you. Schlossplatz is one of them. The old stones seem to hold quiet stories, and the evening light paints the buildings like someone is brushing the city with love. I just stood there, listening to a violinist, soaking in the moment. If you're nearby - don't rush past. There's a kind of peace here, even in the middle of the crowd.
Great place to visit and grab a bite to eat. Beautiful and very picturesque. We were there during UEFA Nation's League Cup and the atmosphere was electrifying

Stuttgart's Schlossplatz is so much more than just a large, central square-it's the city's living room. Stepping onto the expansive grounds, you immediately feel the weight of history meeting the lightness of modern life. The sheer grandeur of the New Palace, with its creamy fa√ßade and stately presence, is captivating. Yet, what makes Schlossplatz truly special isn't the architecture alone, but the way it's used.
On a sun-drenched afternoon, the green lawns are a patchwork of people enjoying life. Students studying, friends sharing a picnic, families letting their kids run free-the atmosphere is one of relaxed, communal joy. The ornate fountains, with their gentle splashing, provide a soothing soundtrack to the urban buzz. And at the heart of it all, the Jubilee Column rises like a proud sentinel, crowned by the elegant figure of Concordia, the goddess of harmony. This monument, built to honor King Wilhelm I, perfectly encapsulates the plaza's purpose: a space for the people, for unity, and for shared experiences.
I've seen Schlossplatz transform from a vibrant open-air concert venue to a magical Christmas market wonderland, complete with a skating rink. It's the place where the city celebrates, mourns, and simply exists. It's a reminder that a city's soul isn't just in its buildings, but in the people who bring them to life. Whether you're a tourist or a local, spending time at Schlossplatz is not just visiting a landmark; it's participating in the heartbeat of Stuttgart.

places.generalDescription: Staatsgalerie Stuttgart is a vibrant museum that showcases a permanent display of 20th-century art alongside special exhibitions of prints, drawings, and photographs. The neoclassical-meets-contemporary architecture by British architect James Stirling gives the gallery a unique and colorful exterior.

sources.snippet: From one look at the colorful exterior of Stuttgart's State Gallery, you know it's not another stodgy museum. The 1984 opening of the new building, designed by James Stirling and itself a masterpiece of contemporary architecture, marked the transformation of the museum into one of the finest art collections in Europe - and one of Germany's most visited museums. Although it has an excellent representation of German Renaissance art, as well as Dutch and Italian masters from the 14th to 19th centuries, the Staatsgalerie is best known for its outstanding collection of 20th-century paintings.
sources.shortName: Attractions & Things to Do in Stuttgart

sources.snippet: Das Herz der Stadt ‚Äì umgeben von fotogenen Geb√§uden von historisch bis modern: Der Kubus des Kunstmuseum Stuttgart (auch nachts spektakul√§r), das Neue und das Alte Schloss (sch√∂ner Innenhof), die K√∂nigsbaupassagen, die Brunnen, der charmante Pavillon und die zentrale Jubil√§umss√§ule. Der Schlossplatz bietet mehr als ein Motiv. Tolle Perspektive: Von der Freitreppe neben dem Kunstmuseum habt Ihr den √úberblick!
sources.shortName: Top 10: Foto Spots

sources.snippet: This excellent art museum started out in 1843 and is still partly set within its original Neoclassical building. In the 1980s the architect James Stirling helped raise the museum‚Äôs profile with an ambitious Post-Modern extension. The newer annexe holds 20th-century art by Matisse, Picasso, Salvador Dal√≠, Franz Marc, Piet Mondrian and Joan Mir√≥.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Stuttgart (Germany)

sources.snippet: This outstanding art museum was opened in 1843 and is now partially set in its original Neoclassical building. The architect James Stirling helped lift the museum's image with an innovative postmodernism expansion in the 1980s. The newest annexe houses paintings by Matisse, Picasso, Salvador Dal√≠, Franz Marc in the 20th century.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Stuttgart

sources.snippet: There are quite a lot of art museums in Stuttgart, but the Staatsgalerie Stuttgart is probably the most popular one. Inside, you‚Äôll find an eclectic mix of old masters, Bauhaus and modern paintings. They usually also have a temporary exhibition.
sources.shortName: The top 15 things to do in Stuttgart, Germany [A local's guide]

sources.snippet: Mittlerweile wurde die alte Staatsgalerie durch die neue erweitert. An manchen Ecken findet man vereinzelt einzelne Statuen und auff√§llig farbige Kunstelemente. ¬© Quelle: Von Praesepe65 ‚Äì Eigenes Werk, Wikipedia
sources.siteName: Vereinigung Stuttgarter Studentenwohnheime e.V. | Studentenwohnheime in Stuttgart
sources.shortName: 5 Instagram worthy spots in Stuttgart

places.name: Staatsgalerie Stuttgart

reviews.text:
The Stuttgart State Gallery (Staatsgalerie Stuttgart) is a real treasure for art lovers. It houses an impressive collection of paintings and sculptures spanning several centuries, from the Renaissance to modern art.

Particularly impressive is the collection of 20th-century works: works by Picasso, Dali, Kandinsky, as well as German expressionists. The interior of the gallery is very bright and thoughtful, and the architecture combines classical and modern elements.

A special plus is the convenient location. If you are interested in art, this is definitely a place to visit.

A must-visit spot in Stuttgart! The architecture is striking both inside and out, blending modern design with classic elements. The collection is diverse, featuring everything from old masters to contemporary works. The layout makes it easy to navigate and enjoy the exhibits at your own pace. Staff were friendly and helpful. Great experience overall - highly recommended for art lovers and curious travelers alike!

This gallery was amazing to visit. It is so big you really could spend hours here if you wanted to take your time. Houses a whole room dedicated to Picasso with a dozen or so of his pieces. Also many other famous artists throughout the gallery like Modigliani, Renoir, Monet, Degas, Warhol. I went on a Saturday at lunch and expected crowds but it was fine and not too busy. And all for only 10euro entry. I love Germany.

places.generalDescription: Nestled within the enchanting Rotwildpark in Stuttgart, B√§renschl√∂ssle is a beautifully reconstructed Roman-style pleasure palace from the 1800s. This charming spot is perfect for hikers and cyclists looking to immerse themselves in nature while enjoying a delightful break. Accessible via scenic woodland paths from Vaihingen University or by public transport, it offers visitors an opportunity to explore miles of trails surrounded by fascinating wildlife.

sources.snippet: Discover the idyllic paths around the B√§rensee, an absolute favorite place to relax üêª The lake and the cosy B√§renschl√∂ssle offer the perfect little break in the countryside. Enjoy delicious food and a fantastic view of the Hirschwiese meadow and the picturesque park lakes. Also a highlight in winter with a frozen lake and snow - perfect for a winter hike or a hot chocolate.
sources.shortName: Discover Stuttgart's green side: Top places and parks to relax

places.name: B√§renschl√∂ssle

reviews.text:
Peaceful place.
Great for a walk around the three lakes and a stop for a bite to eat or drink a coffee afterwards. Everything is great.

Food was really good here, but the desserts weren't that impressive. There's a menu written with chalk, and one picks the dishes from the list and orders at one of the 3 counters. The food is ready really fast, so even though there's a big line at the entrance, it doesn't take too long for it to move. There are tables inside on the ground floor, where the food is also ordered, and there's a second floor with more tables. There are also tables on the outside and when the weather is nice there's even some benches and a beer garden. The bathrooms are accessible from the outside, but as these can be used by anyone visiting the Pfaffensee, they tend to be a bit dirty. It's a very nice place to come with visitors, family and children, but it's a bit on the expensive side.

A great place for refreshments after visiting the Glems river and the lakes. The prices are reasonable and the staff is very friendly. The place is overcrowded on weekends. The toilets are usable, but not very clean (especially on weekends).

places.address: *Direkte Zufahrt nicht erlaubt !, Mahdentalstra√üe 14, 70569 Stuttgart, Germany

places.generalDescription: Ascend the Stuttgart TV Tower, a renowned landmark offering breathtaking city vistas and an adrenaline-pumping experience for thrill-seekers. This architectural gem stands at 217 meters tall and features open-air viewing platforms at around 150 meters, providing unparalleled panoramic views of Stuttgart, the Neckar Valley, the Alb, the Black Forest, and the Odenwald. Delve into its history at the on-site museum before savoring a meal at its restaurant while soaking in the mesmerizing scenery.

sources.snippet: The world's first television tower would be interesting enough, but the 217-meter-tall ((710 ft)) Fernsehturm Stuttgart has the added attraction of observation decks and a restaurant, with sweeping views that reach across the city and Neckar Valley into the Swabian countryside, as far as the Black Forest and the Odenwald. This attraction can be a fun diversion for families but appeals to everyone. Ride the elevator to the top and enjoy the 360-degree views from one or both observation decks.
sources.shortName: Attractions & Things to Do in Stuttgart

places.name: Stuttgart TV Tower

reviews.text: Prob the tallest tower in Europe n the view from up there is wild! Lift takes just 36 secs to shoot u up. Saw Stuttgart from way above-stadiums, highways n all. Def worth it. If u can, carry a binocular for extra fun at the top. A must-do spot!

The TV tower in Stuttgart is an impressive landmark and well worth a visit. It is included in the Stuttgart card, and there is also free parking right at the site which makes the visit easy. The ticket office doubles as a small souvenir shop with many interesting items, adding to the sense of arrival. Going up just before sunset proved to be a magical choice, as the city and surrounding hills slowly changed colour with the fading light. The panorama from the top is wide and striking, stretching far across the region. It is one of those places where the timing of your visit makes a big difference, and sunset truly enhances the experience.

A striking feat of engineering and a symbol of post-war innovation in Germany. Completed in 1956, it was the world's first television tower built using reinforced concrete; an architectural model that inspired towers worldwide, including those in Toronto and Johannesburg.

Standing 217 meters tall, the tower offers panoramic views of Stuttgart, the Neckar Valley, and even the distant Alps on clear days. A high-speed elevator takes you to the observation deck, where the city unfolds in all directions.

Informative displays at the base explain its construction and global significance, making it more than just a lookout, it's a monument to modernist vision. Whether you're an architecture buff, a history lover, or just chasing the view, the Stuttgart TV Tower delivers a sky-high experience with substance.

places.generalDescription: The Old Castle, originally constructed in the 10th century, is a significant historical site in Stuttgart. Adjacent to the New Palace, it once served as the residence for the rulers of Baden-Wurttemberg. Today, it houses part of the W√ºrttemberg State Museum and features an impressive collection that includes archaeological finds from UNESCO World Heritage sites in Blaubeurren & Swabian Jura.

sources.snippet: Right next to the New Palace, you‚Äôll find the Old Castle where the rulers of Baden-W√ºrttemberg lived before they decided they needed a more lavish place to represent their might. Inside, you‚Äôll find the Landesmuseum W√ºrttemberg, which is beyond magnificent. The archeological department houses some of the most important finds from the UNESCO World Heritage in Blaubeurren & Swabian Jura, though there is also an amazing treasure vault and quite interesting exhibits from the celts or the Romans.
sources.shortName: The top 15 things to do in Stuttgart, Germany [A local's guide]

places.name: Old Castle

reviews.text: The Altes Schloss Stuttgart is not only an architectural treasure but also a key piece of Stuttgart's history. The legacy of Eberhard I, who helped shape its development, remains visible throughout the structure. Whether you're interested in medieval history, royal architecture, or regional art, the Altes Schloss is a must-visit for anyone looking to understand the rich history of Stuttgart and the House of W√ºrttemberg.

I have been here many years ago alone  and now in April 2025 I came back with my husband and children. Very beautiful museum! Interesting for adults and children. You can see the crown of kings and queens. Coins, armor, swords.

Built in 10th Century the magnificent structure would of had many uses throughout its history. But it was built as a Castle originally where lots of battles would have transpired near here, today its a historical monument to the brilliant architectural design & engineering standards which now houses a museum

places.generalDescription: Santiago de Chile Square, nestled in Stuttgart-Haigst, is a hidden gem that offers breathtaking panoramic views of the city. Accessible via the charming cogwheel train known as "Zacke," this serene spot provides an ideal escape from the hustle and bustle. With its elevated position at nearly 500 meters, visitors can soak in stunning vistas of Palace Square and Charlotte Square while enjoying a peaceful atmosphere with minimal crowds.

sources.snippet: Einer meiner Lieblingsorte der Stadt ist der Santiago-de-Chile-Platz. Der Foto-Spot liegt hoch √ºber der Stadt und bietet bei sch√∂nem Wetter einen unglaublich sch√∂nen Ausblick. Hier ist es auch oft gar nicht √ºberf√ºllt.
sources.shortName: Die sch√∂nsten Foto Locations, Instagram-Spots, Tipps und Sehensw√ºrdigkeiten in Stuttgart - inspirationdelavie

places.name: Santiago de Chile Place

reviews.text: Great viewpoint. For full experience would recommend getting the Zacke after for more nice angles!!
Very nice view - Stuttgart from the top!
A great overview of stuttgart ... chilling in summer and beautiful lights in clear winter days.

places.generalDescription: Schillerplatz is a grand and historic cobblestone square located in the Old Town of Stuttgart. It features a statue commemorating Friedrich Schiller, a renowned German poet, philosopher, historian, and dramatist. The square hosts a vibrant flower market on Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday mornings and is also part of the annual Christmas Market in December.

sources.snippet: Flanking the Old Palace is Schillerplatz, an old town square with a monument to Friedrich Schiller, poet, philosopher, historian, and dramatist - one of Germany's most famous cultural giants. The square is the site of a flower market on Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday mornings, and in December joins the Schlossplatz and Marktplatz, on either side of Schillerplatz, as home to the Christmas Market. One side of the square is formed by the Alte Kanzlei (Old Chancellery), and on the southwest side is the old Fruchtkasten (Granary) dating from 1390, and adjoining it, the choir of the Stiftskirche.
sources.shortName: Attractions & Things to Do in Stuttgart

sources.snippet: Eines der sch√∂nsten Fotomotive in Stuttgart haben wir am Schillerplatz gefunden, der als historischer Kern der Stuttgarter Altstadt z√§hlt. Er wurde in seiner heutigen Form zu Ehren Friedrich Schillers angelegt, dessen Denkmal seit 1839 in der Mitte des Platzes steht. Umgeben ist der Schillerplatz von der Stiftskirche, dem Fruchtkasten, dem Prinzenbau sowie dem Alten Schloss.
sources.shortName: 15 Sehensw√ºrdigkeiten, Fotospots & Aktivit√§ten

places.name: Schillerplatz

reviews.text: Schillerplatz is considered Old Town of Stuttgart. The square is smaller but beautifully designed and the architecture is beautiful. Highly recommend.

This is a small and charming urban square in the Old Town of Stuttgart named after German Poet Friedrich Schiller (1759-1805). The square is fairly small but nicely framed by Altes Schloss, Stiftskirche and other nice buildings.

There is a early 19th-century monument of Schiller worth seeing and the square is a major part of the annual Christmas Market being filled with highly decorative stalls and large crowds at this time of the year. It was quite the festive scene during our recent visit.

Schillerplatz is a stately cobbled square in Stuttgart's old town, anchored by a commanding bronze monument to Friedrich Schiller, one of Germany's most revered poets and playwrights. Erected in 1839, it was the first public monument in Germany dedicated to a civilian. Today, it's surrounded by Renaissance architecture and lively caf√©s, offering a dignified yet inviting place to pause amid the city's historic heart.

places.generalDescription: The State Museum of Natural History Stuttgart is a treasure trove for anyone fascinated by the wonders of our planet. As one of Germany's largest natural history museums, it boasts an impressive collection of over 11 million scientific objects, including more than four million fossils that span millions of years. Visitors can marvel at captivating dinosaur displays, such as the prosauropod Plateosaurus and various marine reptiles like ichthyosaurs and plesiosaurs.

sources.snippet: With over 11 million objects available for viewing, the Natural History Museum just north of downtown Stuttgart is one of the largest in the country. Check out fossils up to 250 million years ago, and learn about the natural history of the area.
sources.shortName: 28 Unique Things To Do in Stuttgart, Germany [2025] -

sources.snippet: If you are traveling with kids, then the Naturkunde Museum has to be on your list of things to do in Stuttgart. It‚Äôs quite an interactive place with lots of taxidermies of the most popular species on this planet.
sources.shortName: The top 15 things to do in Stuttgart, Germany [A local's guide]

places.name: State Museum of Natural History Stuttgart

reviews.text: The State Museum of Natural History at Stuttgart is a unique collection of several hundreds of dinosaurs, fossils, vertebrates, plants, insects, pre-historic humans etc and is one of the most important repositories for natural collections. Housed in three floors, it is also a great place for kids to watch and enjoy. Tickets are @5/3 Euros for adults/seniors and no charges for kids. There is a Cafeteria for snacks, beverages and ice creams. A shop inside offers soft and hard toys of animals for sale. The staff are helpful and great.  It is great place to spend the day with family and children.

they did a fantastic job. You can clearly see the story of how life evolved, presented in an engaging way.

However, I noticed that many visitors seemed to get lost along the way, as the layout is not very clear or concrete. The web app also malfunctioned frequently, requiring me to reload it several times, and some stations lacked numbers for the audio guide. Despite these issues, the audio guide was still far better than those I've encountered in other museums.
The dinosaurs outside attracted me and reminded me of my childhood, I had to go in and wasn't disappointed. Sure, small and cute museum but, amazing to visit.

places.generalDescription: Impressive tower built in 1904 to honor Bismarck, one of a series, with a beacon for lighting.

sources.snippet: The Bismarck Tower in Stuttgart not only offers you an impressive view of the city, but also great green surroundings. Explore the idyllic hiking trails and enjoy the peace and quiet surrounded by nature. The tower is the perfect spot for a break with panoramic views and green experiences.
sources.shortName: Discover Stuttgart's green side: Top places and parks to relax

places.name: Bismarckturm Stuttgart

reviews.text: Fantastic view of Stuttgart. A place to walk and relax. The road is narrow but still free parking can be found. The other side of the road is offered also for afternoon sun bathing.

My favourite viewpoint in Stuttgart! You can see the beautiful city centre and landmarks from here all the way to the iconic TV tower (Fernsehturm), take in the lush green hills while sitting peacefully on one of the many benches or low stone walls, or walk along the many paths leading up and downhill from this scenic point. Accessible and open 24/7 with no tickets needed, this is a great spot to hang out at or visit. To watch the sunset you can just cross over to the other side of the street for another panoramic hill. There's even a table tennis table, although it can often be too windy to play, given the openness of the area. Definitely recommend visiting if you're in Stuttgart, no matter the season!

One of the most beautiful spots in Stuttgart.
There‚Äòs a large garden that‚Äòs great for chilling, grilling and drone flying.

Breathtaking overview.

places.generalDescription: Middle Schlossgarten is a beautiful and serene park located in the heart of the city of Stuttgart. The park is popular for picnics and walking, and features flowers, a pond, and a playground. There are no vendors, so bring your own food.

sources.shortName: Die sch√∂nsten Foto Locations, Instagram-Spots, Tipps und Sehensw√ºrdigkeiten in Stuttgart - inspirationdelavie

places.name: Mittlerer Schlossgarten

reviews.text: A park very nice near to the hbf station of the city. There is a lake to walk around and everywhere do you have a good view from the park. In some cases it's possible to get in a elevate to a better view from the city and the park
Great place to take long walks in the nature; there are alot of playgrounds and a beergarden where you can feel yourself like you are in the Spring Fest, or Oktoberfest, depending of the Season.

The park is located at a good central position in the city center. However, it seems that much work is in progress and some parts of the park aren't accessible or the view isn't nice as you see only construction sites.
There are also some old ruins but there's a fence around them so you can't enter or take a closer look. A few fountains also exist but they have no water. A small lake though has water and some ducks and fish. When constructions are completed it may look way better.

places.generalDescription: The City Library at the Mail√§nder Platz in Stuttgart is a modern, cube-like structure with a minimalist and light-filled interior. It offers a unique reading experience with books from various authors and printers worldwide. Visitors can relax and enjoy their reading in the basement lockers or savor snacks from the cafeteria. On sunny days, they can even read on the open roof terrace, which provides stunning city views and a wonderful atmosphere.

sources.snippet: Stuttgart City Library is so far removed from the various library clich√©s with its marvelous, minimalist approach to decoration and books from all different authors and printers from around the world on all subjects conceivable. This library wants to be visited; there are even lockers in the basements so that visitors and tourists can just relax and enjoy their reading. The snacks from the cafeteria are wonderful and on sunny days visitors can have the delight of reading on the open roof top terrace, which boasts a stunning view and a wonderful atmosphere.
sources.shortName: Top Things To Do And See In Stuttgart, Germany

sources.snippet: Stuttgart is the capital of the federal state of Baden-W√ºrttemberg and has around 600,000 inhabitants. This makes it the sixth largest city in Germany after Berlin, Hamburg, Munich, Cologne and Frankfurt.
sources.shortName: Top 15 sights, photo spots & activities

places.name: City Library at the Mail√§nder Platz

reviews.text: Most modern library I have been to in Europe so far. Stunning interior architecture with a large open centre, revealing the different floors. The material in the library covers a wide range of topics. Ample reading and studying areas with sofas, desks and workstations.

l think it was best library I have ever seen. It was very close to station and the center. The design is very nice. It can be visited freely. There is a cafe on the top floor. there are resources from all languages in one section, cleverly.

Free entry and super easy to visit if you're strolling around the city. The interior design is simple and clean but somehow still feels unique. There's a caf√© on the top floor where you can kick back and relax, plus you can head up to the rooftop to take in a great view of the city. It's the perfect spot to pause and soak up the atmosphere.

places.generalDescription: Birkenkopf, also known as "Monte Scherbelino" or "Mount Rubble," is the highest point in Stuttgart, standing at 511 meters above sea level. It is a literal mountain of rubble from the ruins of the city after World War II. The hill serves as a memorial to the war's victims and a warning to future generations.

sources.snippet: Birkenkopf is a literal mountain of rubble cleared from the ruins of the city following Allied bombing in the Second World War. That masonry added an extra 40 metres to a hill that now crests at 511 metres above sea level and has a prominence of around 300 metres over the Neckar River. A walk to the top is an opportunity to reflect on the war, and a large piece of rubble beside at the summit has a plaque stating that the hill is a memorial to the dead and a warning to the living.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Stuttgart (Germany)

sources.snippet: 511 Meter H√∂he ergeben einen ziemlich spektakul√§ren Ausblick √ºber den Kessel. Nimmt man noch das monumentale Kreuz und die Ruinen und verbliebenen Fassaden der umliegenden, im 2. Weltkrieg zerst√∂rten Geb√§ude hinzu, erh√§lt man den Foto-Hotspot im Stuttgarter Westen.
sources.shortName: Die 7 besten Fotospots in Stuttgart

sources.snippet: Auf dem 511 Meter hohen Berg l√§sst sich die Stadt aus der Vogelperspektive fotografieren ‚Äì ein wahrlich gro√üartiger Fotospot. Der Birkenkopf gilt als der h√∂chste Berg im Stadtgebiet. Bekannt ist der Berg f√ºr das Kreuz, das als vielseitiges Fotomotiv verwendet kann.
sources.shortName: Die 33 besten Fotospots + Tipps zum Fotografieren in Stuttgart

sources.snippet: To get a glimpse of history and a great view at once, head to Birkenkopf. Also known as Rubble Hill, this hill has been built up by rubble and remnants of war. This is evident by the pieces of buildings overgrown by shrubs and grass.
sources.shortName: 28 Unique Things To Do in Stuttgart, Germany [2025] -

places.name: Birkenkopf

reviews.text: A place with historical importance and a stunning panoramic view of the city of Stuttgart. I went there on Silvester and the view of the city was simply unforgettable. It's also a good hike to reach the top.

A war memorial constructed from WWII rubble, Birkenkopf symbolizes Stuttgart's post-war reconstruction. Standing 511 meters high, it provides a historical perspective on the city's destruction and rebuilding efforts while offering scenic views.
Easy climb uphill with a fantastic view of Stuttgart and its suburbs. Accessible via private cars and public transportation. From the Parkplatz downhill, it's an easy 10-20 mins trek uphill.

places.generalDescription: Nestled in Stuttgart, Max-Eyth-See is a stunning lake and nature reserve that has transformed from an old quarry into a beloved recreational haven. Locals affectionately refer to it as 'The Eythy,' and it's easy to see why! This enchanting spot invites visitors to unwind amidst lush greenery, making it feel like you've stepped into a fairy tale.

sources.snippet: Max-Eyth-See is one of my favorite places to photograph water fowl and other animals. The best part for me is the interaction between people and animals. The lake is a little oasis in the middle of the big city.
sources.shortName: Local Photographers Choose :The Best Spots For Photography In Stuttgart

sources.snippet: Relax on the shore, enjoy a picnic or take advantage of the sports facilities such as beach volleyball and boat hire. üõ∂üí¶ (Unfortunately, you are not allowed to swim in the lake). All infos for the location
sources.shortName: Discover Stuttgart's green side: Top places and parks to relax

places.name: Max-Eyth-See

reviews.text: I came here on a weekday afternoon and felt really nice to see walk around for any age group. Worth every minute.

Nice park to begin with , long trails for walking , jogging, and bicycling . You can relax by the lake on one of the benches , grab a bite in one of the surrounding restaurants , take the boat for ‚Ç¨7 for 30 mins, come with family and friends and use the barbecue grills, or sit on the beach chairs and sun bathe. Parking available in more than one spot around the lake. I visited the park on a moderately hot weekday and the clouds saved us every now and then from the heat of the sun . The only missing star is because the lake is full of moss, smelly in some parts and that restricted the area where we can go with the boat and made peddling a hard task.

Awesome place for walk, boating, hiking, PARTY (you can grill there, use your tents to stay) (you are allowed to grill 8am-8pm)

Toilets are also there same like in other fests.

sources.snippet: Die neugotische Johanneskirche ist eines der Architekturhighlights im Stuttgarter Westen (in dem sich auch einige besonders sch√∂ne Stra√üenz√ºge (z.B. Senefelder Stra√üe) befinden). Und mit dem sch√∂nen Feuersee im Vordergrund bietet das Ensemble ein faszinierendes Foto-Motiv.
sources.shortName: Top 10: Foto Spots
Dein Street Photography Guide f√ºr Stuttgart (2024)

reviews.text: A good relaxing point in the centre of the Stuttgart city. A small pond around the church looks beautiful with a fountain in the centre. People usually relax on a sunny day around the pond and can be sometimes crowded. There is also few cafes next to the pond. Grab some coffee and stroll around the pond and enjoy the lovely weather üòâ
Good place enjoy peace
Great spot for socializing and taking and afternoon chill. You can find benches , ice cream, snacks and even a toilet there. Can't get any better!

places.generalDescription: Step into the rich history and architectural grandeur of Stiftskirche in Stuttgart, a historic church dating back to the 10th century. This inner-city church is adorned with art, stained-glass windows, ancient bells, and a majestic pipe organ. The structure's Romanesque and Gothic styles reflect centuries of religious significance and cultural heritage.

sources.snippet: Right in the heart of the city, you will find the Sfitskirche (‚Äúcollegiate church‚Äù) ‚Äì the most important Evangelical-Lutheran Chuch in W√ºrttemberg. It was bombed heavily during World War II, but its foundations can actually be traced back to the 10th century. The interiors are rather plain and functional, but it‚Äôs two characteristic bell towers are still one of the most famous landmarks in Stuttgart.
sources.shortName: The top 15 things to do in Stuttgart, Germany [A local's guide]

sources.snippet: The collegiate church in the Innenstadt has the same outline as a church constructed much earlier, in the 900s. The oldest architecture on the current building is Romanesque style and from the 13th century, with later extensions in an Early Gothic (nave) and then High Gothic style (choir). The current church was built by the 13th-century Count Ulrich I, who resided close by at the Old Castle.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Stuttgart (Germany)

places.name: Stiftskirche, Stuttgart

reviews.text: I had the opportunity to worship in a very old church with some wonderful people. It was an anniversary celebration, and they played beautiful songs. However, the service here is in German and starts at 10:00 AM every Sunday.

It's a beautiful church located close to Stuttgart's city center. There are many caf√©s and restaurants nearby, making it a great place to visit and spend some time. It's also within walking distance of Stuttgart Central Station.

Stiftskirche is Stuttgart's oldest church and a defining feature of the city center, with roots dating back to the 12th century. Its architecture reflects a layered history; Romanesque foundations, Gothic towers, and post-war modernist elements added after heavy WWII damage.

The church's twin towers create a striking silhouette, and its role as the burial site for W√ºrttemberg royalty adds historical weight. Surrounded by shops and caf√©s, it stands as a quiet anchor to the city's past amid the modern bustle.

places.generalDescription: The Weissenhofmuseum im Haus Le Corbusier is a museum dedicated to the modernist Weissenhof Estate, featuring semi-detached houses designed by the renowned architect Le Corbusier. This architectural ensemble, known as the Weissenhofsiedlung, showcases the largest collection of Bauhaus architecture in the world.

sources.snippet: Le Corbusier‚Äôs building was intended as a showcase for his International style, and this pair of semi-detached houses has since become a museum. They have his trademark clean lines, demonstrating the technical possibilities created by materials like steel, concrete and glass to increase airflow and the amount of natural light inside. One of the semi-detached houses is a museum about the Weissenhof Estate, with lots of interesting details like plans, models and contemporary photos of the buildings that have been lost.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Stuttgart (Germany)

places.name: Weissenhofmuseum im Haus Le Corbusier

reviews.text: Cosy little place, not swarmed by tourists, and the museum curator are very friendly and converse in English well. A must if ypu are a fan of le corbusier architecture or a fan of brutalism / modernist art.

Amazing Place with Deep Connections to Design History üëèüèº
Such a beautiful and inspiring experience! The site has strong ties to the houses in Dessau, Weimar, and Brno, which made the visit even more meaningful. My family and I truly loved exploring this gem at the top of Stuttgart. The Weissenhof Museum is a must-see for anyone interested in architecture and modernist designüëåüèº
Beautiful renovation with one side set up for exhibits and the other meant to recreate the original.  Would be great if they could keep one unit in the Mies building open to the public.
